title: Chinese Government cancels RMB 49.7 million of Government of Cape Verde’s outstanding debt obligations
description: On July 12, 2001, the Chinese Government and the Government of Cape Verde signed a partial debt exemption protocol agreement (中华人民共和国政府和佛得角共和国政府关于免除佛得角政府部分债务议定书 or Protocolo sobre a anulacao parcial das dividas do Governo de Cabo Verde entre o Governo da Republica de Cabo Verde e o Governo da Republica Popular da China). Under the terms of this agreement, the Chinese Government agreed to cancel the Government of Cape Verde outstanding debt obligations related to 3 interest-free loans: an RMB 20 million interest-free loan contracted on July 25, 1980, an RMB 9.7 million interest-free loan contracted in December 1984, and an RMB 20 million interest-free loan contracted on May 30, 1986.
staff_comments: This project is not marked as umbrella since the loans being forgiven were contracted before the time frame of the dataset (2000+).
combined_text:
# Sector
ACTION RELATING TO DEBT

# Title
Chinese Government cancels RMB 49.7 million of Government of Cape Verde’s outstanding debt obligations

# Description
On July 12, 2001, the Chinese Government and the Government of Cape Verde signed a partial debt exemption protocol agreement (中华人民共和国政府和佛得角共和国政府关于免除佛得角政府部分债务议定书 or Protocolo sobre a anulacao parcial das dividas do Governo de Cabo Verde entre o Governo da Republica de Cabo Verde e o Governo da Republica Popular da China). Under the terms of this agreement, the Chinese Government agreed to cancel the Government of Cape Verde outstanding debt obligations related to 3 interest-free loans: an RMB 20 million interest-free loan contracted on July 25, 1980, an RMB 9.7 million interest-free loan contracted in December 1984, and an RMB 20 million interest-free loan contracted on May 30, 1986.
justification: Debt cancellation agreement without specific environmental or energy transition implications
evidence: Debt exemption protocol agreement, financial restructuring focus

title: Chinese Government provides grant for Chinese Medical Team Housing Project
description: On December 20, 2001 an exchange of letters was signed between China and Cabo Verde for the Chinese Medical Team Housing Project. In 2002, the China’s Ministry of Commerce (MOFCOM) provided a grant to the Government of Cabo Verde for this project. The monetary value of this financial commitment is unknown. However, it is known that the Chinese Government committed EUR 1.9 million for this project and the Praia Central Hospital Surgical Ward Construction Project (captured in Project ID#53192). Therefore, for the time being, AidData estimates that MOFCOM evenly divided the funds across the two projects (committing EUR 950,000 to each project).   The Chinese Medical Team Housing Project involved the construction of housing units for Chinese medical teams stationed at Agostinho Neto Hospital (HAN or Praia Central Hospital or 普拉亚中心医院) in the capital city of Praia. The construction area occupied about 750 square meters.   On June 25, 2003, five Chinese engineers arrived in Praia to make preparations for the implementation of the project. Construction began on December 2, 2003. Then, from August 18-26, 2004, five Chinese experts carried out a mid-term project inspection on behalf of MOFCOM and found its implementation to be excellent. On August 30, 2005, the project was officially completed handed over to the Government of Cabo Verde. The Chinese Ambassador to Cabo Verde Sun Rongmao and Director General of International Cooperation of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs Anthony Alves Lopez signed the project handover certificate on behalf of the governments of China and Cabo Verde.
staff_comments: The Chinese project title is 建设中国医生住房 or 中国医生住房. The Portuguese project title is Construcao da Residencia para a Equipe Médica Chinesa. AidData could not identify any evidence from the Chinese Government or the Government of Cape Verde that this project was supported by a loan. Therefore, it is coded as a grant-financed project for the time being. However, MOFCOM refers to the project as being supported by ‘aid’, which in principle could be a grant or interest-free loan. This issue merits further investigation.
combined_text:
# Sector
HEALTH

# Title
Chinese Government provides grant for Chinese Medical Team Housing Project

# Description
On December 20, 2001 an exchange of letters was signed between China and Cabo Verde for the Chinese Medical Team Housing Project. In 2002, the China’s Ministry of Commerce (MOFCOM) provided a grant to the Government of Cabo Verde for this project. The monetary value of this financial commitment is unknown. However, it is known that the Chinese Government committed EUR 1.9 million for this project and the Praia Central Hospital Surgical Ward Construction Project (captured in Project ID#53192). Therefore, for the time being, AidData estimates that MOFCOM evenly divided the funds across the two projects (committing EUR 950,000 to each project).   The Chinese Medical Team Housing Project involved the construction of housing units for Chinese medical teams stationed at Agostinho Neto Hospital (HAN or Praia Central Hospital or 普拉亚中心医院) in the capital city of Praia. The construction area occupied about 750 square meters.   On June 25, 2003, five Chinese engineers arrived in Praia to make preparations for the implementation of the project. Construction began on December 2, 2003. Then, from August 18-26, 2004, five Chinese experts carried out a mid-term project inspection on behalf of MOFCOM and found its implementation to be excellent. On August 30, 2005, the project was officially completed handed over to the Government of Cabo Verde. The Chinese Ambassador to Cabo Verde Sun Rongmao and Director General of International Cooperation of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs Anthony Alves Lopez signed the project handover certificate on behalf of the governments of China and Cabo Verde.
justification: Project focuses on housing construction for medical teams, unrelated to energy or environmental impact
evidence: Construction of housing units for Chinese medical teams, healthcare sector focus

title: Chinese delegation donates technological equipment to Cambodian Minister of Fine Arts
description: The Chinese Cultural Delegation donated six sets of computers, a camera and microphone equipment worth 150,000 CNY to Cambodia November 15, 2001. The Chinese Cultural Delegation, headed by Deputy Minister Pan Zhenshou handed over the equipment to the Cambodian Minister of Fine Arts, Princess Norodom Bophadevi in a gesture of good will.
combined_text:
# Sector

# Description
The Chinese Cultural Delegation donated six sets of computers, a camera and microphone equipment worth 150,000 CNY to Cambodia November 15, 2001. The Chinese Cultural Delegation, headed by Deputy Minister Pan Zhenshou handed over the equipment to the Cambodian Minister of Fine Arts, Princess Norodom Bophadevi in a gesture of good will.
justification: Project involves donation of technological equipment for cultural purposes without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Donation of computers, camera, and microphone equipment to Cambodian Ministry of Fine Arts

title: China donates criminal investigation equipment to the Cambodia Ministry of Interior
description: According to a media report on October 17, 2001, the Chinese government provided Cambodia with 30 sets of criminal detection equipment worth 550,000 CNY (67,400 U.S. Dollars). The equipment will be distributed so that each province or municipality has one. The government of China signed the receipt for delivery of equipment with the Minister of Interior of the Kingdom of Cambodia. The equipment is very important for the Ministry of Interior to detect criminal cases, since in the past criminal evidence must be sent to neighboring countries, such as Thailand, to be detected.
combined_text:
# Sector
GOVERNMENT AND CIVIL SOCIETY

# Title
China donates criminal investigation equipment to the Cambodia Ministry of Interior

# Description
According to a media report on October 17, 2001, the Chinese government provided Cambodia with 30 sets of criminal detection equipment worth 550,000 CNY (67,400 U.S. Dollars). The equipment will be distributed so that each province or municipality has one. The government of China signed the receipt for delivery of equipment with the Minister of Interior of the Kingdom of Cambodia. The equipment is very important for the Ministry of Interior to detect criminal cases, since in the past criminal evidence must be sent to neighboring countries, such as Thailand, to be detected.
justification: Project involves donation of criminal investigation equipment with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Criminal detection equipment donation, government and civil society sector

title: China donates forensic equipment to Cambodian police
description: According to a media report on October 23, 2001, China gave Cambodia a gift of forensic equipment worth 80,000 dollars. This donation included materials that would enable Cambodian authorities to find clues from fingerprints and blood. This donation would provide the Cambodian police with forensic investigation capabilities, where previously, the authorities have to rely on forensic specialists from neighboring Thailand and Vietnam or did not use forensic investigation techniques at all.
combined_text:
# Sector
GOVERNMENT AND CIVIL SOCIETY

# Title
China donates forensic equipment to Cambodian police

# Description
According to a media report on October 23, 2001, China gave Cambodia a gift of forensic equipment worth 80,000 dollars. This donation included materials that would enable Cambodian authorities to find clues from fingerprints and blood. This donation would provide the Cambodian police with forensic investigation capabilities, where previously, the authorities have to rely on forensic specialists from neighboring Thailand and Vietnam or did not use forensic investigation techniques at all.
justification: Project involves donation of forensic equipment to improve police capabilities, with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Forensic equipment donation, focus on police investigation capabilities, no energy or industrial components

title: Chinese Government helps Cambodia Drill 500 Wells
description: On September 7, 2001, Chinese Ambassador to Cambodia Ning Fukui handed over 500 tube wells to Ly Thuch, Minster of the Rural Development, at the city of Kompong Speu, capital of Kompong Speu province. This is the second grant aid of China in rural water supply sector development in Cambodia; the first grant aid of 500 tube wells was already awarded in April 1999.The total 1,000 tube wells for drinking water can provide about 250,000 people in the rural areas with clean drinking water.  In 2002, the Chinese Government granted RMB 16 million for Cambodia's Water Well Drilling Project (captured in ProjectID#32040).
combined_text:

justification: Project focuses on providing clean drinking water through well drilling, which is a social development initiative without direct environmental or energy transition impacts

title: Chinese Government provides RMB 45 million grant  — via ETCA — for Phase 1 of Steel Bridge Materials Project (linked to #32095, #32019)
description: On July 18 2001, the Chinese Government and the Government of Cambodia signed an RMB 45 million grant agreement for Phase 1 of the Steel Bridge Materials Project. These grant proceeds were drawn from an Economic and Technical Cooperation Agreement (ETCA) that the Chinese Government and the Government of Cambodia signed on November 13, 2000 (as captured in linked ProjectID#32019). The purpose of the project was to supply 1,000 meters of HD200 highway steel bridges. The ultimate goal of the project was to construct 48 steel bridges.  China Xi’An International Economic and Technical Trade Corp. was the contractor responsible for implementation. The project was officially completed and handed over to the Cambodian Government on June 17, 2002.  The Chinese Government also funded Phase 2 of the Steel Bridge Materials Project (captured in Project ID#32095).
combined_text:

title: Chinese Government provides RMB 16.41 million grant for Senate Library and Office Construction Project
description: On November 10 2001, President of the Cambodia’s Senate Samdech Chea Sim and Chinese Ambassador Ning Fukui laid the foundation stone for the Senate library and office building. The project was a request by the Royal Government of Cambodia to the People’s Republic of China, and the initial agreement was signed in June 20, 2001. The project is part of the Exchange of Notes concerning assistance on Economic and Technical Cooperation extended by China and Cambodia to strengthen the relationship between two countries. This project should be done within 9 months. Construction was carried out by Yanjian Group and is expected to cost 16.41 million yuan.
combined_text:

The project is part of the Exchange of Notes concerning assistance on Economic and Technical Cooperation extended by China and Cambodia to strengthen the relationship between two countries. title: Chinese Government provides RMB 16 million grant — via ETCA — for Water Well Drilling Project (linked to #32019)
description: According to an agreement between the Chinese Government and the Cambodian Government signed October 15, 2002, the Chinese government would give nearly US$1.9 million (or in some reports, 16 million CNY) to drill 500 water wells in Cambodia. The wells will be partly financed from remaining funds (RMB 5 million out of RMB 50 million) granted to Cambodia in the Agreement on Economic and Technical Cooperation signed November 13, 2000 (as captured in linked ProjectID#32019).  The wells are expected to be located in Kampong Cham, Kampong Speu, Kampong Chhnang, Kampot, and Krong Preah Sihanouk. The drilling ceremony for the wells occurred on December 30, 2002, and the handover ceremony for the wells was held on July 13, 2004.  This is the third batch of wells the Chinese government helping build in Cambodia. The Chinese government has previously granted 1000 tube wells to Cambodia from the period of 1996 to 2001 (See Project ID#32035).
combined_text:

title: Chinese Government provides $1.7 million grant for Preah Ket Mealea Military Hospital Renovation Project (Linked to Project ID#32020)
description: On February 13, 2001, China’s Ministry of Defense and the Cambodian Ministry of Defense signed an RMB 30 million ($3.7 million) grant agreement (see Project ID#32020). Then, on May 8, 2001, the Government of Cambodia announced that the Chinese Government had agreed to earmark $1.7 million of the grant proceeds for the renovation of the Preah Ket Mealea Military Hospital (មន្ទីរពេទ្យ​ព្រះកេតុ​មាលា:) in the capital city of Phnom Penh. The project involved the procurement of construction equipment in order to renovate the five-story building and improve nearby drainage and roads. Construction was slated to begin in November 2001, according to Co-Minister of Defense Prince Sisowath Sirirath. The project was ultimately completed in 2005. In 2007, four Chinese medical experts were dispatched to the hospital (as captured via Project ID#62711).
combined_text:
